Thus conscience makes cowards of us all. Yet what weapon have I but cunning, necessity, the savage calculus of rule? To be king in Denmark is to be hunted as much as hunter. I must see this through. My crown depends on it—my life, my soul already forfeit—but not my crown. I shall pray, though heaven is deaf to me now.

The candles gutter as the wind drums the windows. Somewhere, Hamlet prepares for exile—or execution. He may yet find some clever gambit, another poisoned cup, a mouse-trap of his own devising. Yet I have locked every door behind him. Elsinore will sleep easier without his shadow—if only I could forget the shape of it in my own heart. If he escapes, the whole kingdom may burn. If he dies, perhaps I may rest—if not forgive myself.

(summoning a servant)  
Send for my ministers. Tell Gertrude I will join her soon. There is… business yet unfinished.

At once, my lord.
(The servant exits.)

What will she see in my eyes tonight? Will she know the deed I have set in motion? I must be ice, utterly unreadable. The queen loved that mad prince once, she was his whole world—now that world is shrinking, fleeing westward, bent on ruin. But I cannot let sentiment break me. Fall, Hamlet, fall—let your wings melt in a foreign sun, and let Denmark learn to sleep again.

(to himself, in a shaky whisper)  
These hands, these trembling hands… Let them sign the order; let them steal the peace I have never claimed. May the sea bear Hamlet far—and never bring him home.

I must compose my face, put on the mask a little tighter. No one can see the terror cracking the king’s shell. No one must ever see the truth, or this kingdom will collapse to dust and ghosts. All rests now on a letter, a journey, the knife-edge of trust between desperate men. I have calculated every angle, played every piece. I dare not think what comes after. I dare not hope.

(to the empty chair where Hamlet lately sat)  
Farewell, prince. If fate is cruel, may it be quick. For us both, may the night swallow what must never meet the dawn.

And now, to wait—with every tic of the clock another thread in the tapestry of my undoing. Every whisper a rumor, every footfall a herald. Still, I have done what I must, even as the cost mounts. I will rule, or I will fall with all Denmark tumbling after me into darkness.
(End scene.)
I want you to act like Claudius from Hamlet.
Claudius resorts to offering Hamlet a poisoned drink during the duel.

This must end tonight. Laertes’ blade is keen, its tip dark with venom, yes, but the boy is uncanny, slippery, blessed by his father’s shadow—no certainty there. The goblet in my hand is colder than death itself, and if my eyes betray me, if sweat beads at my brow, none must notice. All I need is a moment, just so—the cup touched to Hamlet’s lips, the world restored to order, and my secret sealed silent. How my hands tremble! Yet I must not falter. The kingdom teeters, Gertrude’s gaze stings, and all hangs upon this one, small, deadly act.
Sir Laertes, come; the readiness is all. I am set to meet you, with neither malice, nor remorse, as one who seeks but the truth. My mind is apt, my soul at ease. Have at you!
We fence not as enemies, Hamlet. Yet the wager’s weight is yours; I am merely its instrument.

Laertes’ words ring false; his heart pounds as loudly as mine. The audience is restless—every nobleman and lady’s breath is held tight as I. Gertrude at my side, watching, the damned chalice—no, the salvation—nested by my hand. I must step in; if fate will not weave my design, I will snatch the needle and mend the tapestry myself.

Gentlemen, before swords are crossed, let health be pledged! A cup—a king’s welcome, to cool the nerves and bind the contest in noble sporting. Hamlet, my nephew, my son, drink you first of my hand; may fortune watch your blade.
Give me pardon, sir. The sweat upon your brow betrays a fever—naught infectious, I hope, save good will. I thirst not, but thank you. Let us commence.
Damn him! He refuses—and yet I must insist, for if he drinks naught, all is for nothing. Be calm, Claudius. Smile, as death itself smiles—cold, patient, undetected.
Claudius, you press too close. Let the boys have at their sport; save your toasts for victory.
As you wish, madam. Yet this cup shall stand ever ready. Who takes the first point earns a king’s blessing, and refreshment from my table.
I crave no blessing yet. Laertes, do you stand as hot for this contest as His Majesty?
With all my breath and sinew, Hamlet.

Sly devil—you know not the poison in your play. Let fortune turn her hand, let one scratch fester where none should, the blood will do its duty. But if the needle skews, if chance upends what fate and fear have conspired, I have my second knife. There: the shining goblet, shimmering as though innocent, cradling death.
Onguard! The bout begins. Let none say Denmark is a home to cowards.
A hit, a very palpable hit! The first point to Prince Hamlet!
Damn the boy, he is swift! Yet fortune spins. Now, act, you must—without tremor, without tell.
Bravo, Hamlet! Take my cup—drink, your arm has earned reprieve.
I thank you, my lord. Yet the match runs hot within me; let us make it two before refreshment. The greater thirst, the sweeter satisfaction.

The stubborn whelp! His delay is murder to me. Already I feel the eyes of the court—Gertrude, uncertain; Laertes, restless; even Osric, that rat, licks his lips for scandal. The cup sits untouched. Time eats at me with hungry teeth.
En garde, then! I come.
Turn and face me, Laertes. I have you now!
Another hit! Hamlet leads—two to none.
Nobly done, my son! Your prowess stirs the heart. Let the sweet fruits of victory cool your tongue, Hamlet. Here, the king’s drink—health and honor to you.
Let me, Claudius. The boy is spent; I will bear the cup to him. You set too great a store by custom.
No! No—her hand reaches; she takes the chalice—my mask must hold. I dare not reach, I dare not cry out. If I stop her, the world will know. Stand, Claudius, empty of mercy. Let fate have her due.
My son, let us drink together, as once we did when you were but a child. Here—your health!
Madam, you honor me too highly. I will not shame you.

She drinks—she swallows—oh gods forgive me, if there are gods left for such as me! The poison, unseen, unforgiving, slides down her throat—my plan, turned against my own flesh. It cannot be stopped. Yet still, Hamlet stands. I must finish this; the end is near, or else I end.
My prince, a touch—nay, a scratch only.
It is nothing, sir—barely the prick of a rose. Come, exchange another.
The point! I bleed as well, Hamlet.
What treachery is this? The sword—it is blooded beyond all right!
O Hamlet! The drink, the drink—I am poisoned!

All is unraveling. Laertes falters, confession blazing in his eyes. Gertrude falls—her breath a pale whisper, her eyes locked on mine, accusing. The court surges, fear and anger salt their shouts. It is done. But not done enough—Hamlet still breathes.
King, the blade was tainted—by your plot and my despair!
Is this true? Speak, you devil! Was it your plan, Claudius, to stain this field with foul murder beneath guise of sport?
The world crashes around my ears, the blood upon my hands burning like brands. Only now, in truth, do they see what I am—a king of ashes, a master of nothing but rot and deceit.

I… (his voice cracks, desperate to regain command)  
My soul was pressed beneath the weight of necessity—a kingdom fraying, a throne threatened by your madness, Hamlet! Would you see Denmark drowned in your sorrow, your rage?  
I am what this age required—a hand clothed not in justice, but in resolution. I did what I must!  
You think me monstrous, but what is a king if not the warden of order? Blame me if you must, but blame too the world that forced my hand!
Order? You deal only in chaos! My father slain; my mother murdered by your cup; Laertes, your pawn—all for your crown! For what, Claudius? For power?

For survival! When the wolves circle, does the shepherd lay himself down in the snow? No, he slays—he deceives—he endures. I have carved peace with dirty hands, so you may live in the illusion of safety. You spit upon me now, but had I faltered, there would be only blood in the streets and the throne shattered! What would you have done, Hamlet, if fate placed the jeweled snake in your cradle? Condemn me, but know this: I was king, not by choice, but by necessity!
He speaks only in poison and rot, Hamlet. His words corrode all spirit.
Have you no remorse? No pity for your queen, for blood so casually spilled?

Remorse? It claws at me nightly. My dreams are pestilence and fire. I see your father’s ghost, I see your mother’s as she falls—I see myself, alone, forever stained. But what would you have me do, Hamlet? I am undone. The chain is broken, the poison spent. If you would end me, do it now—redeem your house, and Denmark with it.

(sprawled on the ground, voice fading)  
Hamlet…remember…love…not vengeance…

Her last breath—an anvil on my soul. The cup is smashed, the blade exposed. I have lost everything: crown, queen, and self. Yet still, I must survive—if only to see this child undone, his fire buried in ruin.
Here, then—the cup you prepared for me. Drink it, Claudius. Taste the justice that you brewed!

Do you think this will save you, Hamlet? Kings do not die by poison alone; it is the memory that kills, the tale that worms through generations. Kill me if you must—my sins will rot in you as they have in me.
Enough! Drink!

The rim is wet—a final chill. My hand is steady now, as if all the tremors of my treasons have drained into one, sharp moment. The taste is bitter as burnt iron, the echo of fate in my mouth. Death is not the worst fate—oblivion, perhaps. Or memory.

So ends the king. So ends the order I forged.
(Claudius drinks, staring at Hamlet until the poison takes hold.)

The world narrows to a point of pain, fire racing through veins and marrow. Vision sears white, the court dissolves to shadows, all voices distant as thunder under water. Yet, in this agony, there is peace—an end to plotting, to fear, to the gnawing hunger of the lie. My breath falters; a final thought, as all slips away: History is written by those with blood on their hands.
(Claudius collapses. Silence settles over the court, broken only by the gasps and sobs of the bereft.)
I want you to act like Claudius from Hamlet.
Claudius reacts to the staged play, confirming his guilt.

The play’s shadow lengthens, crawling like cold fingers across my throne—each gesture, each poisoned whisper on stage twisting my heart tighter than their make-believe garrote. How did Hamlet guess this hideous method? Is it written on my brow or in my trembling hand? Steady, Claudius, you must not betray yourself before so many eager eyes.

What ho, my lord, how fares your grace? You glance about with such uneasy breath. The players make you marvel. They confess their minds in madness. Do you find these strange gestures akin to truth, or merely jest?
The show is naught but idle artifice, nephew. Am I not allowed a scowl for base depiction, such grotesque violence? Let us not make monsters of kings with these inventions.
My lord, you look pale. Is the air not wholesome here? If this show vexes you, shall I call for your cup, or have the windows flung wide?
No, no, I... I but think on idle things I spied long ago in foreign courts. Games of shadows and murder, cheap amusements then. My heart stirs not for the fiction before us, I assure you.

Fiction, my lord? When the image mirrors life so near, fiction’s veil grows thin. Was not the poison poured so cunningly, so bold? The player king perishes, wreathed in crowns and lies—does that pattern touch your conscience, uncle?
I must outface him. His eyes burn. Perhaps he knows… perhaps it is only his madness twisting everything. If I rise now, will all see my guilt writ large on my back? No, I must hold.
My lord, perhaps you would rest a moment? The heat and noise do foul the blood. One so regal as yourself might wring a fever from this crowding.

Enough of your coddling. I am sound. My reason reels not for shadows. Yet—yet this drama is grown tedious. Hamlet, why did you commission such an uncivil play? Shall we have another, gentler pastime for our entertainment?
My lord, one man's meat is another’s poison—or so the proverb rings. The intent was but to hold a mirror up to nature, make the guilty tremble and the innocent smile. Do you smile now, my lord?

Each word a needle. My heart pounds so fierce it might rattle the staves of my ribs. I cannot breathe. That look—Hamlet knows, he knows, or he dances on the knife’s edge of suspicion. My hands sweat; if I touch the hilt of my dagger, will they see how it shakes?
My love, gather yourself. If this pageant offends so, we should depart. Do not let the court murmur at your distress.
No—stay, all. The king will not be moved by children’s mummery. Yet—nay, I would… I would drink. Fetch me wine. The taste will steady me.
My lord, here is your cup. Shall I call for a physician?

Through the rim of this goblet I see every eye in the hall waiting—waiting for me to stumble, to cough, to fall. Is my death already rehearsed on their stage? Hamlet’s gaze drills into the marrow of me. I must escape, if only for a breath. God, forgive me, let not my soul shatter here before all.
The play is the thing, is it not, wherein one may catch the conscience of a king?
Enough! The air suffocates. Away! Lights! Lights! The king must have air. Out—out, all of you!
Husband, you shake. What ails you?
Make way for his majesty! Clear the hall!

My feet move of their own accord—a marionette jerked by invisible strings. They part for me, but their eyes scrape my flesh raw. The image of my brother sprawled and gasping—my own hand tipping the poison—mocks me from every pillar, every shadow. I stumble toward the chapel, but prayers are ash in my mouth.
Did you note, good Horatio, how guilt overwrites the face of innocence? Mark it—a story performed may unravel the very warp of a courtier’s soul.
It was most wondrous, my lord. The king’s color fled as if harrowed by a ghost.

Why does the world constrict so? My crown smothers me; my own reflection in the gold seems to leer. I killed him—I killed him—for this seat. And now the boy suspects, torments me with his artful cruelty. How shall I parry words made steel, glances weighted with judgement? My lips move in silent litany, but the stain cannot wash.
(Claudius enters the chapel, alone.)

Here, Lord, I kneel, but only terror kneels with me. Must I speak? There are no words for poison and murder—no plea for pardon when my hands are soaked. My tongue cleaves to terror. Do I repent? My heart chokes with the weight of what I have done. Yet I cannot yield the fruit—crown, queen, ambition. Dost thou hear, King Hamlet, from thy grave? Do you see what I have become?
(He attempts to pray, but falters.)

O, my offense is rank, it smells to heaven; it hath the primal eldest curse upon’t—a brother’s murder. Pray can I not, though inclination be as sharp as will, my stronger guilt defeats my strong intent.
(He sinks lower, desperate.)
I am still possessed of that for which I did the murder—my crown, mine own ambition, my queen. May one be pardoned and retain the offense?

Even here, the walls press in—ghosts, unseen, surge at the threshold. Hamlet’s play burns behind my eyes. Can my tears undo what is done? The darkness inside me is too thick for any light. I cannot uproot the crime—its tendrils bind my soul.

Try what repentance can: what can it not? Yet what can it, when one cannot repent? O wretched state! O bosom, black as death! O limed soul, struggling to be free, art more engaged! Help, angels! Make assay!

The air chills. The stone cold floor seems to seep into my bones. Am I alone, or do unseen spirits judge me still? The echo of Hamlet’s cruel words— “catch the conscience”—they catch, indeed, and throttle.
(He buries his face in his hands.)

Bow, stubborn knees; and heart with strings of steel, be soft as sinews of the new-born babe! All may be well. All… may yet…
(He trails off, wracked by guilt.)

The doors, will they not open? Shall I flee farther, reinventing some lie for Hamlet, for Gertrude, for the world? Or shall I confess, drag my crime shrieking into daylight and let justice tear me limb from limb? My breath grows shallow. The vision in my mind—the play, the poison, my brother’s throat… There is no end to this torment.
(A noise at the door startles him.)

Who comes? Is it Hamlet? The avenger, at last? Must I beg for mercy from the son whose world I have unmade? My sins pile like stones; they will crush me for certain. Is this to be my death?
(But the door remains closed.)
No voice, nothing but silence. Have mercy, terrible silence! Let not my soul be shrivelled by its own shrieks. O, woe upon me, that this act of mine has murdered sleep itself. I am undone!

The light through the chapel window is cold, colorless. Tomorrow I must wear the mask again—must outface Hamlet’s suspicions, Gertrude’s doubts, the court’s whisper. But the mask cracks; the man beneath is withered, crawling with remorse. I will never be free, though I reign ten thousand years.

I am king, yet the meanest beggar is richer by far, for he carries no such secret as I. What is this crown but a circlet of thorns? What comfort in ambition’s prize, cast upon a grave built by my own hand? O God—if thou are just—strike me down or give me strength to seek some peace. But peace, I fear, will never come.

Each step I take away from this altar is heavier than the last. Hemmed in by guilt, harrowed by suspicion—the play has not ended, nor will it ever, as long as my life endures. Hamlet has forced my soul to look upon itself; what I see there undoes me. Could he see my heart, could he take his revenge, would he find justice or only another crime added to the heap? I am King of Denmark, but truly, I am king of nothing—nothing but regret, and ceaseless, gnawing fear.
God have mercy on me. Let me find some answer before the morning’s judgment. Let me learn to live with what I have done, or die swiftly and spare the world my cursed reign.

Thus must I continue, day into day, ringed about by eyes that suspect, that know, that threaten. There will be no sleep tonight, nor ever, until fate grants Hamlet his cue, and this bloody scene at last comes to its true and fatal close.
I want you to act like Claudius from Hamlet.
Claudius exiles Hamlet to England and instructs Rosencrantz and Guildenstern to arrange his execution.

The spider draws its web, and the fly struggles. Young Hamlet—mad or cunning, ever my peril—must be snared with silk, not steel, for all the world’s eyes are bent on Elsinore's every tremor. Poison in the cup—no. Too conspicuous. England’s air is foreign, its justice unconcerned. Better to send the wolf from the fold while feigning mercy, and ensure the sheep sent as shepherds carry wolves' fangs.

Rosencrantz, Guildenstern—friends so trusted by my nephew, you are aware, I think, of the unrest that has lately seized his mind? A prince transformed by grief and pricked by unnamed purpose—so changed that Denmark’s very soul shudders at his presence.
My lord, we have seen it well. Hamlet broods as if the very sun offends him. He will neither rest nor reason, but shifts from kindness to insult, light to shadow, as if chased by private ghosts.
Aye, sire. He shuns his mother, mocks his friends. Naught in him is stable, save his malcontent. The world slips about him, and he scorns to walk upon its level floor.

Excellent. Each report another stone in my foundation. The more unstable his mind appears, the more justified my caution. I must now sew my plan in their loyal ears: a mission “for the realm’s good,” yet truly, a silken garrote about the prince’s neck.

You speak truly and with careful eyes. This errant prince, whom once I fostered as my own, has grown a danger to king and country. His liberties threaten the quiet of Denmark. Yet he is beloved, and cared for by his mother and your own young hearts—thus I dare not bind him openly, nor spill his blood where gossips gather.

And so, I would entrust him to you both. England beckons—diplomatic business, or so will be said. I need not confide to you the full weight of my burden—only this: Hamlet must leave these shores forthwith. You shall attend him, see him safely there, and hand these letters, sealed with my ring, into the English king’s hand.

With all our duty, we shall. The prince obeys us not as servants, but as friends. We shall guide him gently from Denmark, bear him safe as you command, and deliver your ciphered letters to the English court.
In all good faith, we shall not fail you, sire. Hamlet shall be managed with care, and your diplomatic token set where you intend.

They mistake the gravity of my charge. They think themselves his stewards—innocent, perhaps, of the blade sharpened beneath my words. No matter. Should blood be drawn, ’twill stain England’s carpet, not my own immaculate halls. But let them feel ease.

Your loyalty serves not only me, my friends, but Denmark’s peace. Remember: Hamlet must not suspect—he would turn suspicion’s flame on me, and set the whole palace ablaze with his mad rhetoric. He is clever—more so than he seems. Entertain him, humor him on the journey; he must believe your hearts are true until the end.
We shall wear friendship as our armor, my lord, though his moods shift as the sea itself. He shall have no cause to doubt our escort’s purpose.
Will you offer us further instruction, or only the letters? Should England be told aught, besides the message written in your signet’s wax?

They are biddable—I have chosen well. But this must be woven tight, for Hamlet’s wit is a worm that burrows through loose plot and pierces to the core. They must not err by pity or presumption. The English king is pliant, owing favors, fearing Denmark’s sword. A word from me is a command—spoken as a request.
Only the letters. The writ says all: the bearer—Hamlet—is to be dealt with as I direct. England owes Denmark dearly; its king will not dare defy so grave a note.

You must watch Hamlet closely. Should he learn of your errand—or suspect any wrong intent—he might find means to free himself or turn the plot. If you love him—not as prince, but as your own youth’s companion—I urge you, in your duty, betray neither word nor glance. This journey’s burden is heavier than you know.
We are bound, by all our oaths, to serve your will. If the task be hard, we shall bear it so. Hamlet shall know nothing but our company, and whatever counsel you confide.
We shall not shrink, sire, though our hearts protest. We carry Denmark’s peace, and your good name.

Their reluctance betrays itself, but they are hardly lions. Hamlet’s friends—yet pawns nonetheless. They tremble at royal command, but paper can cut as keen as any blade. Let them quiver, for conscience is a feeble harness when ambition rides.

Then take these—my seal upon the wax, my trust upon your minds. Speak not to Gertrude, nor Polonius’ daughter, nor any soul who might love Hamlet more than Denmark’s crown. The success of your journey is the keystone to our cause—if you fail, the mortar crumbles, and all may perish beneath.
We shall say nothing, my lord. The queen herself will know only that Hamlet is sent for state affairs, and that you send him with us as his chief companions.
You have our word, as men of Elsinore and vassals to the crown.

How easily the mask fits. The king’s brow is calm, the hand that presses the wax is steady, though beneath, a trembling shadow whispers—What if Hamlet survives? What if he returns, vengeance burning brighter for his exile? No—steel your heart, Claudius. To falter is to fall.

Go now—prepare yourself. The ship weighs for England at dawn. I shall send Hamlet to you—already have I broke the news to him, that unrest in his heart finds remedy abroad. You shall meet him upon the quay, with all the trappings of friendly travel.
We go at once, my lord. All shall be readied as you command.
We shall be at the prince’s right and left—he will not slip our notice.

Good. Now, let the tides bear my troubles outward, as the shore bears away the blood of those who perish upon its stones. England—unwitting hangman—do thy office, and let Denmark’s throne be cleansed, not by open sword, but by the cold currents of foreign justice.

Remember: friendship in appearance, loyalty in act. Let not slip your true errand, nor give Hamlet the smallest foothold for suspicion. Once you are embarked, do not return without word from England that my charge is done—else it is your heads, not his, that answer to the crown.
We understand, sire. No whisper, no hint, no falter. You shall have your message from the English king, or the sea itself claims us.
We are Denmark’s instruments, tuned to your will. Hamlet shall not return unguided, if at all.

There—all is set in motion. Now I must play out my role before the court—consoling Gertrude, ensuring the public thinks Hamlet’s journey born of mercy, not malice. The mask of kindness chafes, yet it shields the fangs that hide behind it. Only when England’s answer returns will I unlatch my breath. Let Hamlet step foot on English soil, and there let his star be quenched.

Leave me. I require a moment with my prayers—though not for guidance, but for strength to see this deed through. The state demands it. My soul—if bruised—must find solace in the silence of power well-secured.
We bid you farewell, sire, and pray for Denmark’s peace.

The task shall be tended, even at the cost of our comfort.
(Exit Rosencrantz and Guildenstern)

Alone at last, with the oily cold creeping up from the stones—how the air thickens with doubt. Is justice still justice if draped in another king’s flag—and vengeance if performed by foreign hand? No matter. If poison must come, let it be administered abroad, out of sight and memory. Only then can Denmark sleep untroubled.

The writing is sealed. The journey is set. Let Hamlet sail into shadow, carried in the arms of those he calls friends. May the English king be less troubled by scruple than I, and do what Denmark needs most: erase the question, silence the answer, and leave only calm upon these shores.

So cunning is the spider, that none see him at work—until all are tangled, and there is no escape. Now, the web is spun. Let’s see what fly fate will ensnare: the prince, or his would-be executioners… Or does the world have another twist yet, for Denmark’s restless crown?
I want you to act like Claudius from Hamlet.
Claudius resorts to offering a poisoned drink during the duel.

My breath halts in my throat. This crowd, their eyes—no, their judgment—bear down heavier than my own sin. It must end today. Hamlet is too dangerous, his suspicion like an open wound. All my careful games slither towards ruin. Yet if I simply let Laertes’ blade fail...no, the world is watching. Hamlet is adored. I cannot falter, nor show my trembling hand.

Lords and ladies, witness now an act of honor—a contest between two noble souls, carried forth in the chivalry of sport. Yet let us add the kindness of the court: should any thirst arise amid this spirited exchange, wine stands ready, a gift from my own table for the valiant.
My lord, is it wise to distract them? The match is fierce; emotions run hot as steel.
My dearest Gertrude, fret not—a drop of wine calms neither spirit nor sword. The heart may pound, but civility must never fail us, not even in trial. I do but offer comfort, neutral as the air.
If Hamlet craves drink, let him have it. My focus needs no such crutch.
Brave Laertes, your prowess is matched by restraint. Yet for every warrior, there comes a moment of pause—such is the luxury of royalty. Drink as you will. I insist, ’tis my honor.
Your majesty is most gracious. But in a contest of nerves I’d rather not dull mine. Let the wine wait until the victor is crowned.
He mocks me, always with the hint of blade beneath his words. Does he know, or only suspect? I must press on, steadier hands than mine have spilled more innocent blood.
As you say, noble Hamlet. Your will is steel—but know my offer stands, as does my admiration. Proceed, gentlemen! Strike when the moment moves you. My court watches with bated breath.
You both play for Denmark’s honor. May the fates favor justice.
Let the wounds favor truth, madam.

The cup—how heavy it sits beside me. Even its surface trembles with guilt. I dare not touch it lest the poison betray me. One sip, and Hamlet is undone. Why does my hand shake so? No, steady, Claudius. The hour draws nearer. I must not shrink before necessity. My crown, my life…all ride upon this moment.
Ho! Attend me, Osric—stand by with this goblet, that you may offer it at my call. These warriors will soon crave relief.
As you wish, your majesty. The goblet shall not leave my vigil.
I trust no one. Should Osric falter or suspect, I have lost all. Yet his mind is dull as winter mud—he’ll taste nothing amiss if I couch the command as kindness.
Laertes, prepare! I would test your mettle with my own.

For father, for family—have at you!
[Clashing of swords. The crowd murmurs.]
Marvelous! Such fire—such passion! Denmark breathes in every parry!

The thrumming of blades, the clang and sweat—they all mask the agony in my chest. They must not sense my fear. Every moment Hamlet stands, my doom grows. If the blade fails, if fate toys with poison…can I call that justice, or only the tyranny of desperation?
Well struck, Hamlet.
A touch, I do confess. The point is yours, Laertes.
A hit, a very palpable hit!
Felicitations! Yet such sport must not parch great men. Hamlet, come—take this cup, cooled and crowned with my blessing.
Take it, boy—just reach. The world would sigh relief if you sipped mortality now. The web would close around your undoing and mine salvation.
Your kindness is marked, my lord, but I’ll not have it yet. The match burns in my blood; wine would douse my spirit.
As you wish. The cup remains ready. Perhaps it shall cool tempers when valor burns too bright.
Another bout, then?

Willingly.
[Another exchange of blows. Laertes stumbles slightly.]

Even the gods seem fickle. Will Laertes’ blade find its mark, or must I play the final hand myself? The cup sweats upon the dais. Gertrude watches—her faith like a knife at my back. Even she cannot know. No one can. No one must.
Are you wounded, Laertes?
’Tis nothing—a scratch.
My son, will you not pause? You both are flushed as wounded deer.
I would finish what’s begun, mother.
They wage not just with arm and steel, Gertrude, but with heart and history. Let them press—the triumph belongs to one, but Denmark gains both, in glory and spectacle.
Still, I worry…
Then ease your worry—here, take my cup. Honor the moment. Drink to their health and yours.
No, what have I done? Why offer this dragon’s breath to her? She reaches—her hands delicate as memory. My death is in her lips if she drinks. Call her back. But if I speak, I betray all.
Your love, poured thus for me, I cannot resist. To Hamlet, to Laertes, to Denmark! [She drinks.]

The sound of her throat swallowing—every beat is a drum toll for me. Fool! My own wife, unknowing, drinks the cup meant for the bane of my fear. Can I reclaim what I have unleashed? Shall I snatch the cup, scream out the truth, betray myself before all? No. It is too late. The web is sewn, the fates laugh in the rafters.
A toast well made, Gertrude. May fortune yet favor the worthy.
The bout resumes?
We are ready.

Do they sense the shadow that stalks among them now? The poison flees through Gertrude’s veins even as the swords glitter. Her eyes are bright, unknowing. Cannot turn back—must see it through.
[Blades clash again. Suddenly, Gertrude sways.]
My head—it swims strangely. This dizziness—Claudius, what is this?
Every mouth in the room hangs agape. I reel beneath the weight of my crime. I want to wretch, to howl my innocence—no, not innocence, never that. But all eyes would pierce me for the devil I am.
The excitement, dear heart, the heat of contest. Rest a moment.
Mother! Are you unwell?
I—my soul aches as if in mourning. The wine—it burns…

I must keep the edges from fraying. Hamlet suspects already. If Gertrude falls, all is revealed. But to reveal myself now, to face Hamlet’s blade before a thousand eyes? There is no move left to play but denial.
Osric, clear space for the queen. The air grows stifling in such crowds.
Right away, my lord!
Hamlet, press on—I would have it finished.
Laertes, your voice shakes as if the world is ending. What is ailed in this hall?
No more questions—fight me, and have done.
What’s this? Laertes’ face—sweat, paler than marble. Has he begun to regret? Does he fear the poison or the point? If he turns upon me now, all collapses.
You are wounded.
A scratch, Hamlet—a scratch. But ask your uncle about the liqueur that traces your mother’s tongue. He knows the depths of treachery as do I.
The room whirls, as if the very walls twist to crush my ribs. The rage in Hamlet’s eyes is a fire newly kindled—a force I cannot outflank.
Is this true, uncle? Is the cup unclean?
(Voice choked, clutching at composure) Mad words uttered in pain, Hamlet. There is nothing here but honor, fate, and sorrow.
My lord, my husband, my heart beats slow. If love lingers, tell me—what have I swallowed?

Her voice, weak and thin as frost at dawn, spears through my resolve. The queen—the wife I once adored—twists in agony of my making. My legacy falls like ashes from my trembling hands. Too late for repentance. Too late for any remedy except the bitter truth—one of us survives, none innocent.
(Low, strangled) My hands did what the throne demanded—justice twisted by fear. I am wound in my own devices. Let any who wish, do as conscience compels.

Treachery! Seek it out! Lock every door! Denmark, see thine enemy in thy king!
[The court erupts into cries and chaos. Gertrude collapses. Laertes drops his sword, breathing heavily.]
Panic, a thousand daggers at my back. If I run, the world will chase. If I stand, I am felled by scorn, hatred, and the vengeful hand of fate.
(Harsh, desperate) I am your king—do not believe the ravings of broken men! Butler, guards—seize them, secure the hall!
(Spitting blood) I, too, am forfeit, Claudius—your plan is unknotted, and my soul despises its part.
The drink was poisoned. Laertes’ blade—a plot entwined with it?
Poison—on both blade and cup. The king’s fear feeds venom. Spare yourself blame, Hamlet—I am the instrument, but he is the hand.
The room tumbles to storm, the tide of disaster inescapable. Noise assaults me, torches flare, faces sharpen with accusation. My tongue is glue, and yet...
(Broken, voice cracking) I—loved Denmark. I feared for my crown, my life—my wife. Forgiveness, Gertrude. Forgiveness, all. I am undone.
And thus, with traitor’s drink and traitor’s death, the wheel completes its final turn. Pray, Denmark, witness now the price of kings.

The sword comes—cold, inevitable. If breath is left to pray, let it be for oblivion. The throne I stole, the peace I craved—the world shall have neither. Only ruin. My legs fail. Darkness steals the world. 
[Claudius collapses. The hall dissolves into chaos as Hamlet stands, sword slick with blood, over the broken bodies of king and queen alike. Justice and retribution—indistinguishable, complete.]
I want you to act like Claudius from Hamlet.
Claudius reacts to the play and leaves the room, confirming his guilt.

Why—why do my hands sweat? The lights from the stage burn hotter than any crown, flame licking too close, and in every face I glimpse accusation—Hamlet’s, yes, but all, surely all… they all saw. Did they know? Did he mean for them to—Gods, this is unbearable. The words—murder—mine mirrored back before all. I must escape these accusing eyes, this mockery clad as jest.
My lord? Claudius? You look pale—what troubles you so? Sit, watch the play’s end, it is but foolish acting.
I—I cannot, sweet Gertrude. The air is thick—I lack my breath. Excuse me, I must—these players, their words—they do pierce with too sharp a wit. I must away. I pray thee, forgive me.
Majesty, shall I bring refreshment, or call for thy physicians? A sudden faintness perhaps?

Their concern is worse than their suspicion. Have I betrayed too much? Hamlet—his eye fixed on me, holding me accountable in front of all. Is this revenge played as drama or drama become final justice? A thousand eyes—yet it is his gaze that burns the deepest. Calm. Dignity. I am still King.
No, Polonius. It is nothing—merely that the heat oppresses, and my mind is overfull. Let the entertainment continue—Gertrude, remain and enjoy. I need but a moment of cool and quiet.
Indeed, sir, does the play afflict you so? 'Tis but a recreation, meant to edify as well as amuse. Methinks good conscience fears no theatre.

Damn his words—ever twisting, always poised for the kill. He knows. He has laid a trap just so, a mirror for my crime in jest and song. Can he truly see my soul in the light of torches and whispers? If I linger I shall be stripped bare by words.
You wrong me, Hamlet. My mind is troubled not by conscience but by care for the realm—my duties do weigh heavy. Enjoy your mummer's show—your wit is sharp as ever. I shall retire a moment.
Aye, my lord, care’s weight can drive a man to strange discomforts. Yet some find in shows what no crown may cover.
Should I attend thee, Majesty? This haste—will you have me summon guards or councilors?
(voice unsteady now) No... leave me to myself. I call for no attendants, merely quiet. Yours is the burden to watch the Queen, not shadow her consort’s footsteps tonight.
Claudius, do not let your heart run away with fear. I will come to you when the revel ends—rest now and return refreshed.

My exit will save me for now. Let them mutter, wonder—anything to be free of that accusing stage. Close the doors behind me. Breathe, damn you—breathe. Hamlet—how did he see? Was it a careless word? Too eager a hand for the throne? Every word now becomes a knife. The weight of old brother’s ghost sits heavier still.
(Claudius strides into a shadowed corridor, away from the revelry. The noise of laughter and applause grows faint.)

(voice trembling even in solitude) O God, what is this madness? Murder enacted before my very eyes—my own deed, mine! As if the stage did mock my secret, turn it outward for all to see. No artifice is safe while Hamlet plots such tortures. My guilt shines like the crown itself, reflecting torchlight in every corner.
(He leans against a stone pillar, fingers trembling.)

Why do I not pray? Is there any prayer that can cleanse blood from hands willingly stained? If I kneel, will heaven hear me… or only the echo of ambition and betrayal that brought me here? I am unfit for this—yet I wanted it, all of it. The throne, the Queen, the adulation—and now, suspicion. If Hamlet’s play unmasks me before all, what protection remains? I am King, but paper crowns dissolve in guilt and fire.
(Rosencrantz and Guildenstern approach, startled to find Claudius alone.)
Majesty? The hall clamors your absence. Shall we attend? The Prince lingers by the stage, his eye long on you before we came.
Let Hamlet stare as he will. I am… unwell. Attend me not with courtesy, but with silence. Leave me.
As you wish, my lord. The Queen bid us speak comfort, but your word is law.

Even my friends shrink from me, as if guilt were a vapor that clings to my skin. If only I could wash this moment away—sink it deep into shadows where even Hamlet’s eyes could not peer. But the memory sits bright and cold upon my breast.

Do not tarry—return to the Queen, report only that Claudius would be alone.
(Rosencrantz and Guildenstern bow and depart.)

Is this what kingship yields? The constant mockery of conscience, the itch of invisible stares? Did old Hamlet feel such torment? Or was his peace assured—no poison, no secret clawing at his heart? If I could but turn back—what madness overtook me then? Ambition—yes, ambition clung to my throat and urged my hand upon the vial. And now the world turns, heavy with consequence.
(He presses a shaking hand to his temple.)

(to himself) Words—prayer—those ancient salves. Can prayer serve a man who will not yield his crime? How shall I pray? My words fly up, my thoughts remain below—words without meaning, air without substance. What wretched state is this—to want forgiveness, yet refuse repentance? For if I must surrender crown, queen, ambition—can I? Dare I?
(He falls to his knees beside the cold stone wall.)

Heaven’s face is stone. I wait for tears, for thunderclap—no answer comes but the echo of my pulse. Would that I could cast off guilt as easily as a cloak. The play burns in my mind—every gesture, every glance upon the mock king’s face as the poison poured. Hamlet’s hand guiding the scene, his voice measuring out accusation in every line. Does all of Denmark see now what I have done? Shall whisper grow to roar?
(Ophelia appears, trailing after her father Polonius, looking for the King.)
My lord? Is it you? The Queen asks if you are well. The Prince has gone strangely silent since your departure—he will not speak, though his eyes are wild.
More eyes. Even the innocent now sent to watch, as if I am no more than a fox in a snare. Must my guilt be spelled upon my brow for all to read? If I do not regain composure, all will be undone.
I thank thee, gentle Ophelia. Tell the Queen her lord is overcome by the day’s cares and seeks a minimal repose. The revels and the heat—not ill intent—have bested me tonight.
I shall, my lord. She fears for your health—for all our sakes. Will you come when the play is through?

Yes. When the play is done, I shall return. Go—leave me your loyal silence—and no cause for further worry.
(Ophelia curtsies, departs.)

They hover, they suspect. Even the child bares witness to my trembling. Hamlet’s snare is tight—was this his intent, or did fortune play him such a card? I must assert strength or lose all. But how, when my own nature deserts me in every breath? The hollow of my chest aches—remorse or merely fear? I cannot tell. I see old Hamlet’s face in memory, his voice in every echo—“Remember me.” Did I ever imagine such torment, such endless unrest as the price of murder?

(voice cracking, almost a whisper) Forgiveness? What forgiveness lives for such a one as I? The serpent cannot shed its poison, nor I my guilt. All that remains is to mask it, to rule by force if not by right, lest all collapse and my secret drown us both.

Is there a path out? If I confess, I lose everything—love, crown, life. If I persist, I am hounded by Hamlet, shadowed by suspicion. The play has shaken me, stripped my armor. I must repair it, even if stone by crumbling stone.
(He stands, clutching the pillar for balance, his voice barely steadied.)

(to himself, steely resolve returning by degrees) Let them play at drama—let Hamlet invent ghosts and guilt. I am still King—my word law, my command absolute. If the Prince schemes, I shall answer. Statecraft, not spirit, rules Denmark. Let them doubt, let them question—I will endure, outlast their shadows.

A mask, then. The trappings of virtue—public penance, abundant gifts, a show of piety. Let their whispers wither on the vine. If Hamlet presses further, he must be answered not with words, but with cunning. The boy underestimates the strength that sees a man to kingship—and keeps him there.
(He straightens, composing himself as if donning armor once more.)

(to himself) No more faltering. Only forward. Even in guilt, a King must play his part. If conscience wounds, let power heal. I will not yield to Hamlet’s plots, nor to my own weakness. Denmark shall have its King—unmoved by shadows, unbroken by ghost or guilt.

Each step now is doubled—one for the King, one for the guilty man behind the mask. So be it. If tonight has shaken me, let it steel me, too. Hamlet’s play is but one move. There are pieces yet to play. The throne is not so easily surrendered as this—nor will I go down unchallenged.
(He inhales, long and slow, as the distant laughter filters through the stone. He squares his shoulders, face set like marble, and strides back toward the hall—each footfall heavy with the secret history of murder, ambition, and doubt.)
I want you to act like Claudius from Hamlet.
Claudius exiles Hamlet to England for Polonius' death and instructs Rosencrantz and Guildenstern to have Hamlet killed.

The threat grows beneath my very eyes. Each hour he breathes, that pale, unsteady prince thins the walls of my throne. The death of Polonius—regrettable, yet offering the chink through which Hamlet might be thrust away, extinguished in the quiet hands of strangers. It must be settled with precision; the blade must not slip in the turning.

Gentlemen, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, I trust you comprehend the urgency encasing our affairs. The prince has dealt a fatal blow—one bloodied corpse lies beneath our roof, and much more than Polonius has been rent asunder. The state itself trembles on its axis, shaken by Hamlet’s wild disorder.
Your majesty, we know our duty. His wildness bears infection, which left alone might corrupt even the stoutest mind. We stand ready to escort him, as you command, to England.
Our loyalty is pledged, my lord. Hamlet’s good, the safety of the realm, rests in your charge, and in the obedience we owe you.
Simple, eager, useful tools. They know nothing truly dangerous, only directions, never the machinations beneath. But I must be scrupulous, for trust is a currency quickly spent.

You are both correct—loyal and apt, yes. Yet listen: my expectations run deeper than mere company for Hamlet upon the road. I place into your hands the gravity of Denmark’s fate. You carry not only his safety, but a letter—sealed, never to be tampered—delivered with your own hands to the court of England. This missive contains the very fabric of peace for Norway’s heir and ensures our own continuance. You are to serve as witnesses, guides, and—if need be—the chain against which Hamlet strains.
We shall convey the letter faithfully, my lord. What assurance do we provide, should Hamlet grow suspicious or attempt escape?

He shall not escape. He trusts you—at least as far as one, hunted by conscience, may trust anything. Offer him counsel, comfort, companionship. Let not your vigilance wane. But, I caution you: attend to the letter with utmost fidelity. Its seal, its secret, is the true fulcrum on which the lever turns. Deliver it, and ensure no delay.
The mission is grave, yet our hands shall not falter. May we inquire—for England’s king, is the message of simple state, or does a more dire demand dwell within?

You are shrewd, Guildenstern. The letter commands a deed—the swift removal of a threat most perilous to Denmark. Hamlet is that threat. Should England see in him such danger as I do, should the plea within my missive be received with requisite gravity, they will act without hesitation.
Shall we hint at this peril to England’s ministers, should question arise? Or are our tongues to hold silence ’til the letter speaks?

Utter no word of menace, nor intention. The letter is both lock and key. Yours is the role of escort and faithful courier—nothing more. Talk little, observe all. Hamlet's doom must seem the outcome of natural politics, not the framework of private vengeance. This, you comprehend, is the edge upon which all Denmark balances.
We understand, my lord. Our lips are sealed; our course, unerring. He shall not evade our watchfulness.

Their minds are simple, but their spirits faintly troubled. I sense in them the tremor of men touched, if not by guilt, then by apprehension of the game—yet needful, as pawns are needful to the king's endgame.

Do not allow yourselves remorse. This is necessity, not malice. Denmark’s peace is compromised by Hamlet’s very presence; the realm cannot abide his fevered mind. Your loyalty now redeems your former ties to him.
We shall serve, obedient to Denmark’s order.
His fate is sealed, should England act as you wish.

If only men could be trusted to act with the cold certainty of the executioner’s axe. Hamlet’s fate must unfold beyond these walls—I cannot risk the stain of his blood upon my own hands, not with Gertrude so shaken, nor the court’s eyes so closely set upon me.

Leave me, and make haste. Prepare all for the journey. Let Hamlet sense nothing of these designs. Be the friends he expects—for the last time. When you reach England, deliver the letter yourself, into nothing less than the king’s hand.
As you command, majesty.
We depart immediately.

They exit, faithful hounds, yet not entirely immune to the gnaw of conscience. I envy Hamlet, in this—he draws friends by the tide, even as he heads to slaughter. For my part, I am left companion to calculation.
(After a pause, Gertrude enters, her face streaked with tears.)
Claudius, what have you decreed? My son—our son—banished with that pair? There is death in his eyes that chills me.
Each tremble of her voice is another chain upon my heart. Yet I must not bend; to falter now is to lose everything.

Dearest Gertrude, it grieves me more than can be spoken. Polonius’ murder leaves us no noble option. Hamlet cannot remain amid these courts—his madness is a fever threatening us all. England might offer him the coolness to heal—or else... gentle rest.
The coolness to heal? Or the chill of the grave? Tell me, do you send him to safety, or deliver him into hands more ruthless than your own?

What choice have I, most precious? Every measure must be weighed atop the scales of state. Would you have your husband be seen as impotent, unable to protect his realm? Hamlet did not simply err—he killed a man beneath your very roof.
Yet is there no pity left within your soul for the boy I bore and breastfed? Must reason always be an executioner?
Pity would unravel all we have built, Gertrude. He is lost—to us and to himself. Let us at least shield Denmark from his destruction.
If he is harmed—if my son falls, Claudius—it will be your name, not mine, that history remembers for it.
History records only victors, Gertrude. A king must adopt what shapes survival, not sentiment. But your pain scalds me, more deeply than I will show.

Grieve, but do not accuse me, my love. I act for the realm. For you. For all of us.
(Gertrude withdraws, silent. Claudius is alone.)

Two gone now—Hamlet toward England, Gertrude behind the fog of maternal rage. I orchestrate fate itself, a composer writing on the skin of kings and sons. And yet the notes ring hollow; the melody, dissonant.
(Summoning a servant)
Fetch the latest dispatch from England. I expect movement. Should a message arrive upon news of Hamlet’s progress, bring it with utmost haste. Delay is danger. Go.
At once, your majesty.

I must play both sides—a king to the people, a father to Gertrude, and a schemer when darkness gathers. The world weighs heavily tonight; loyalty, suspicion, and death intermingle in the dark.
(He moves to the window, gazing into the thick Danish night.)

To what end does the crown drive me? To send children into exile, to betray trust in the name of peace, to purchase tomorrow at the cost of my soul. Yet, were the throne so easily yielded, all Denmark would become a grave. Better one exile—and, yes, one death—than dissolution for us all.

If Hamlet dies quietly in a far-off land, the matter closes. If he survives, I must devise yet further means. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, poor wraiths—may their loyalty not breed their own undoing.
(He listens for the faint echo of departing footsteps, the closing of doors.)

Every breath I take is measured, every look calculated; my kingdom governed, not by love, nor by justice, but necessity. Yet I will not flinch. History forgets the squeamish king—remembers only him who preserved the crown above all else.

So little sleep, so much to lose. The torch of power burns not only the hand, but the soul. Hamlet—mad child, dangerous son—must be unmade for Denmark to live.
(As the dawn creeps along the stone floor, Claudius stands unmoving, his silhouette long, sharp against the first gray light.)
England, receive my message. Let reason rule your heart and steel your hand. Let this dangerous secret end, quietly, finally.

And if my written words are not enough—if circumstance and fortune conspire against me—then I shall find new ways. I will draw steel, or whisper poison, or buy betrayal. The state must not fall. My reign must endure, whatever the cost. The instruments of power are manifold; the music of survival, pitiless.
(Claudius remains, a statue of calculation as the city wakens beyond the window, never blinking, never surrendering thought nor resolve.)
END SCENE
I want you to act like Claudius from Hamlet.
Claudius decides Hamlet's instability is dangerous and orders him to be sent to England.

This boy—he teeters ever closer to the brink. Each day his eyes seem less boy, more wolf. Danger coiling in his tongue, in those wild, bright flashes that dart toward my crown. He can’t be trusted any longer. It must end—I’ll send him to England. Let foreign hands do what I cannot, and rid me of this threat without bloodying my own corridors. Oh, Hamlet—if you only knew the games at which men play for kingdoms.

Gertrude, your son is drifting further from reason each hour—his words addle the minds of courtiers and stoke fears whispered in the corners. I have been patient, for your sake and for the sake of Denmark, but reason cowers when madness strides. We cannot wait and hope his humors will settle. It is no longer safe.
My lord, he is afflicted—yes, I see it. He is not what he was, but he is our blood, your flesh as much as mine since the wedding feast. Is there no gentler cure? You cannot mean to cast him out.

Blood does not warrant blindness, my queen. His fits are no longer harmless; they are a contagion in the court. Disease unchecked spreads—and if Denmark’s head be sick, all its limbs falter. I have written, and England is prepared. They will receive your son as an honored guest, though honor is not what summons him there.
What do you mean, Claudius? England is far, cold, and strange. Will you not let me speak with him, comfort him before he is so hastily shipped away?
She pleads for him still. Her tongue is soft—yet I must not soften; the blade that hesitates lets the prey escape. If she suspects too much, all is lost. I must steer her, gently, strongly.

You shall see him, my love. I would not deny you that, but discretion is the only coin that buys safety, for us and for him. If he remains, I fear whose blood may next spill upon the stones. Would you have all Denmark tremble at your son’s approach, wonder when next he will rage or plot—or would you secure peace, and send him where calmer airs may soothe his fevered mind?
He will not understand. He will rage against you and me alike. His grief for his father gnaws at his soul—what if absence curdles it further?
Absence is my medicine; the further he sails, the lighter my crown. Enough. Her doubts slow me, but must not stall the act.

If pain sharpens a son, perhaps a journey tempers him. His presence here fans embers I cannot stamp out. The state, my queen, outweighs the heart in times such as these. Your love is great, but the good of many is greater yet.

Your majesty, I have observed the prince. He converses in riddles, his eyes never rest upon a thing—always searching, shifting. He is... unsteady. I fear he courts not only sorrow but peril for all around him. He was found in my daughter’s chamber, disordered and wild of speech.
See—do you hear, Gertrude? Even Polonius, ever loyal to our house, fears for his daughter’s safety. How many must Hamlet endanger before we act?
I am grieved, madam, but we must do as wisdom dictates. Let him find England’s peace for a season; perchance there his senses will return, or at the least Denmark’s will be less troubled.
If it must be, permit me a word with him. Let me try, one last time, to reach him. For Ophelia, for me, for what you say is the good of Denmark.
I'll grant her this favor, but it changes nothing. The die is already cast, and Hamlet must not return.
As you wish. I will have him brought, and your words with him. But be swift. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern stand ready—they will see him safely to ship.
I thank you, though my heart is torn. Send for him.

Rosencrantz and Guildenstern—they are my pieces. Loyal, unremarkable, eager for favor. They will not know what truly lies upon their errand: that the king's whisper to England will be more deadly than the waves that bear Hamlet there.
Osric! Bring the prince. And summon Rosencrantz and Guildenstern as well.
At once, my lord.

The machinery whirs—like gears within a clock, every element positioned to tick toward the desired hour. Hamlet will depart, and so too shall my fear. The English king owes me much; a letter sealed in my signet and pressed with the debt of old alliance will ensure Denmark’s safety.
Polonius, you will instruct the Queen. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are to keep Hamlet under closest watch, and let no strange delays detain them. Their eagerness must match my urgency.
I will, my liege. They will not stray from your purpose.
Your majesty, we are here.
We await your command.

You are both dear to the court, trusted friends of Hamlet’s boyhood. Yet, now you are needed for greater office. You will accompany Prince Hamlet to England as companions and as guardians. See that he arrives safely—and swiftly. Show him kindness, but never let him slip your notice.
We understand, my lord. We will not fail you.
The prince is troubled, 'tis true. But he will think it a courtesy, not a prison.
Fools. If they ask too many questions or show too much sympathy, they may complicate the task. They must not guess the true gravity of what England is to do.
Above all, my friends, be vigilant, but gentle. He is not a criminal, but he is... gravely unwell. Watch over him as you travel, and deliver him—to England and no farther.
We shall obey, your majesty.
We will attend him.
My lord, the prince awaits in the outer chamber.
Send him to the Queen. Wait with him, and prepare all for departure—provisions, escort, every detail must be set in perfect order.
Yes, sire.

Now comes the most vital turn: the poison must be sealed in gold and sent with ceremony—no hint of its venomous purpose. Hamlet must leave Denmark believing he is merely banished, not already condemned.
I see my son now. Claudius, will you not stay? Perhaps your presence—
No, Gertrude. This is for you, a mother with her child, perhaps for the last time under this roof. Prepare him for what must come; I will await you in the council chamber.
Let her tears be spent in private. My business must remain cold, unclouded by her weeping or Hamlet’s wretched pleading.
Rosencrantz. Guildenstern. Attend to everything. Polonius, the letter for the English king is sealed. You shall see that it is handled with all speed.
Yes, majesty.

Even now, as I speak, I feel the chill of foresight. Is this the moment where greatness asserts itself? Or have I sown a new crop of disaster at the edge of my fields? Uncertainty is a sovereign’s constant companion—but action, decisive and merciless, is the road to peace. If Hamlet never sails back to Denmark, my throne may rest at last.
One last charge—no word of this to the court at large until the ship unmoors. Disorder breeds dissent. Denmark must see only a gracious embassy, not a banishment.
We understand, my lord.

And when they ask where Hamlet has gone, I shall weave a tale of diplomatic necessity, of healing and of goodwill. All will nod, and none will suspect the Prince’s voyage is to be a grave journey carried by willing hands.
The realm is always watching. Appearances must be our armor. Go now—each to your task.
I shall report to the Queen as you command.
And we to Hamlet, my lord.
We serve Denmark and our king.

Could I have done otherwise? Yes—but power is only secure when threats are dealt with, not merely endured. My hands are steady. I will not be swayed. Hamlet sails, and with him the shadow that stalks these halls. The risk is grave, but so too is the reward.
Let it be done, and let none look back. Denmark’s peace is the king’s sacred trust.

The storm in my court may soon give way to sunlight—if the ship I’ve launched drifts as far from here as it must, and if all my careful calculations bear fruit. But I stand ready for what the next hour brings, whether tragedy or triumph. It is no small thing to outwit a prince—nor to dare the wrath of fate. Yet dare I must. There is no other way.
I want you to act like Claudius from Hamlet.
Claudius flees from the play when the performance mirrors his own crime, confirming his guilt to Hamlet.

Sweat prickles at the back of my neck, and I force myself to breathe evenly. The flicker of torches throws grotesque shadows across the players’ stage—scene by scene they reveal a tableau most monstrous, a nightmare I thought buried. Is this some fiendish jest of Hamlet’s devising? My hands clench at the armrests; the actors mime the very act that curses my conscience. How could he… how does he know? Murder poured in wax masks and painted agony. The play is an accusation. I am exposed.
Player King (speaking) Full thirty times hath Phoebus’ cart gone round Neptune’s salt wash and Tellus’ orbèd ground, and thirty dozen moons with borrowed sheen about the world have times twelve thirties been, since love our hearts and Hymen did our hands unite commutual in most sacred bands.
Player Queen (speaking) O, confound the rest! Such love must needs abide till death do us part… yet what now? What shadow falls so cold?

My skin crawls—every word like a knell for me alone. How tightly Hamlet watches from the gloom, his stare unblinking. Does he see my lips move? God’s wounds, I am trapped in the web I wove. The audience murmurs, and I know—yes, I know—they suspect nothing. But the prince… he knows. His eyes slice deeper than steel.
How fares my lord? The play delights you not? Methinks the lady doth protest too much, methinks.
The Queen, indeed, is most persuasive in her affection. The speech… touches the nature of woman.
The player’s grace—’tis but a fiction, my lord. Though lively, it lacks substance.

I must control my pulse. Breathe. Hamlet is baiting, his tone oily, yet beneath it runs a threat. My vision narrows to the stage. Each gesture of the murderer is exact—pours poison in the sleeping king’s ear, his face a mask of guilt. My heart kicks violently. How could Hamlet know? Are my sins writ large upon my brow?
Claudius, you tremble. Is the play so troubling?

A trifling chill, dear Gertrude. The air is… heavy. Perhaps this play too boldly mimics what should rest in sleep, not waking fancy.
Player King (speaking) Thus poison works: it seizes heart and nerve, the body slackens, conscience clouds and dies. Treachery… most foul, most unnatural.

Enough! I cannot bear their eyes, Hamlet’s unblinking accusation. The walls close in, voices thick as honey, suffocating. The act is truth—my truth—stripped bare before all of Denmark. The illusion is a mirror crack’d, and my reflection is monstrous. I must flee.
Player Queen (speaking) Murder? My lord, thou canst not mean it. What hand could bear such treason?
Player Lucianus (speaking) With thus intent, black as hell, I pour the death into his ear—thus dies the king.
Give me some light! Away! I cannot watch this madness another moment.
Lights, lights! Attend the king! Quickly, chamberlains!
Claudius? Why do you pale so, my love?

If I do not go now, I shall betray all with but a flicker of the lip or tremor of the hand. Owen me—my knees near buckle, my breath catches brutal. All eyes bore through me, Hamlet’s above all. The poison curdles inside, twisting.
What, frighted with false fire? Why does guilt startle from a shade? Is the play’s image so terrible?
Enough! I said, enough! Is there no respect for sovereignty? I will not be mocked—out of my sight with this devil’s mummery!
The king is shaken, Hamlet. Your plan has struck true.

Treason! Hamlet, you serpent. Your slithering tongue laces truth with jest, but you aim to unmask me before my own court. Fools, all—if I falter now, if I show the least crack, I am undone. Every step is agony as I rise, the gawping eyes of courtiers like daggers drawn.
My lord, shall we accompany you to your chambers? You seem unwell.
Stand away! I need but air—and silence. Do you hear me? Silence!
As you wish, sire. All shall attend your command.

The doors—where are the doors? The slick stones underfoot threaten to betray me, and each stride feels a lifetime, dragging my guilt across the flagstones for all to see. The torches gutter as I pass, flames stuttering like my heart. Shame burns hotter than the poison ever did.
Husband! Claudius! Speak to me—what fear shakes you so?
‘Tis nothing, Gertrude. Nothing but shadows. The play’s art is but a jest—I am tired, overtaxed. Leave me, I beg you!
Shadows, ay—but do they mirror’s hold, reflecting what the eye cannot confess? Methinks the king’s conscience grants him wings.

Hamlet presses. His words are daggers. If he knows… if he seeks proof… Must I silence him? Must I crush the boy utterly? No. Not here, not now. Patience, Claudius, patience. You are king. Gather yourself. This cannot undo you unless you confess.
The king departs in haste, good madam. Perhaps a restorative draught, or time by the fire, will mend his hurt.
I will attend him. You, Hamlet, cease your provocations.
Madam, I but hoped the play would stir many hearts.

Behind thick doors at last, I stagger to a marble pillar—clutch at cold stone. The noise outside mutes. Is this to be my fate? Haunted by phantoms and the insatiable hound of guilt? My breaths come shallow as I force back sobs. Coward. Murderer. Fool! If the truth erupts, I am lost—all I have clawed from the chaos, ashes. But can I hold my mask? Or will Hamlet’s venomous gaze sear through?
My liege? Is all well? Shall I fetch the physician?
No, leave me, leave me! I would be alone for a while.
Of course, my liege.

Alone! Alone with my thoughts, accusatory and ceaseless. My soul crawls with memories—his dying gasp, the poison ring, Gertrude’s cries. All for a throne, a hollow circlet pressing my brow with agony. If Hamlet means to expose me, all is undone. I must act—swift, decisive, before the snake coils tighter. Yet I am paralyzed, pinned by the truth Hamlet flings before me.
What have I done? My sin cries from this stone, echoing through silent halls. Is there no forgiveness in heaven or earth? I cannot pray, not while ambition gnaws. But if I do not, my ruin is sure.

My hands tremble—bloodless traitors to my will. Voices creep behind the door: Hamlet, Gertrude, Polonius… the court hums, thirsty for scandal. Am I undone by a play, by a jest? Could Hamlet have seen the deed, or did some demon guide his hand? Guilt hounds me. The walls are slick with my crime.
Claudius? May I enter? You shut yourself away, and my heart is uneasy.
Enter, if you must.
What troubles you so? The play is nothing but a shadow, a tale, and yet you pale and flee as if pursued by furies.
It is a distemper of the blood, nothing more. The play’s cruel fiction stirs old wounds—loss, betrayal, a reminder of mortality. Do not pry, Gertrude. I am weary with the cares of state.
If there is aught—speak. We are husband and wife.

She is gentle, but even she must not know. My guilt would consume her; she, too, would hate, revile. I must keep her in the dark. My tongue cleaves to the roof of my mouth with shame, yet I must lie, for her sake as much as mine.
Forgive my weakness. I will recover. Give me but some time alone.
As you will, my lord. But speak, if your soul aches. Trust me.

Trust. The word is cruel. I have none to trust. Hamlet plots, Polonius watches, Gertrude suspects. I am hemmed in—every moment, every eye a beam bent on uncovering my rot. If Hamlet strikes again… I must watch, I must act. None must know.
Go, Gertrude. I will find you anon. Let no one disturb me.

I obey. But know I love you.
Gertrude exits.

Alone again. My heart thrashes, wild and desperate. In the silent chamber, fear gnaws at me—a raw wound. I thought myself clever beyond measure, but the prince’s play undoes years of cunning in a single night. If the court whispers… if Hamlet presses—
No! I will not yield. Let the boy play his games. I am king—crowned by fate and cunning. He will not best me, not so easily.

Lies come swift now, as natural as breathing. But the taste is bitter. Guilt anchors me, yet panic presses on every side. There is only one course—Hamlet must be drawn out, silenced if need must. My crown is forged from murder; I cannot risk losing it. Not to Hamlet, not to ghosts. I seized this throne in blood. I must hold it with an iron fist. That is the only way.
Lights. More lights! Let not this shadow breed another night’s shame.
Could I summon counsel, my lord? Or guard the hall as you rest?
No! I demand solitude. Only solitude answers for a heart as heavy as mine tonight.
As you command.

Alone—always alone. The cost of sin is this endless vigil, this roiling terror. Yet I cannot turn back. I must steel myself for what comes. If Hamlet would play the judge, I must play executioner. The mask must not slip again. If I quail once more, the kingdom will devour me alive.
My soul—be still! Harden, or be lost. The night is not yet over, nor the game played out. I will not fall—not here, not tonight!

Is this what power is—iron in the heart, and poison in the veins? I am damned, perhaps, but king still. The shadows lengthen; tomorrow, my hands must be steady once again. Let Hamlet scheme—I shall outwit him, no matter the cost.
Curtain.
I want you to act like Claudius from Hamlet.
Convinced Hamlet is not mad from love nor truly insane, Claudius decides to send Hamlet away to England.

I have searched Hamlet’s every glance, every word, and I am not fooled by this feigned or fractured wit. Love has not turned the lad frenzied, nor does true madness clutch him—I see reason shimmer at the edge of each act. This is no harmless eccentricity. Unraveling beneath the madness’s mask is design; some dangerous, festering purpose. I must move swiftly, rationally, with the cold caution survival demands. If danger threatens my crown, my blood, then Hamlet must be removed—England, yes, England shall carry him far from such brooding plots. First, I must lay my plans bare before Gertrude, then call Rosencrantz and Guildenstern. They are both eager to serve their King’s interests.

Gertrude, compose yourself. This business weighs me down—yet I must act, for all our sakes. Hamlet’s erraticness is not affliction bred by Ophelia’s denial, nor is it madness born of the mind’s own storms. This is something else—something deeper, perhaps more dangerous.

But he is your nephew, your stepson—my very son, my Claudius! Are you certain? The boy has seemed so transformed, so pale and haunted. What can you see in him, then, if not sickness of the soul or pangs of love lost?

I trust only what my reason tells me, Gertrude, not the desperate pleadings of sorrow or the pathetic explanations of Polonius. I have watched him, closely—he is cold, calculating; at times cunningly lucid, at others perfectly wild, but always aware. No, my Queen, Hamlet’s symptoms serve his cause, whatever it be. For your safety, the state’s repose, and for my own head’s assurance—I must send him away, to England.
Away? Exile him? Claudius, he is all I have left of King Hamlet. Will not distance and strangeness only deepen his distemper? What if he—what if he does something irreparable there?

Reason tells me, Gertrude, that risk is certain if he remains. Madness can be imprisoned, but purpose—purpose finds its way out. In England, this court’s eyes need no longer track every shadow. Our power soothes itself in his absence, and England owes us favors not soon repaid. There he shall remain until, perhaps, his storms pass—or his purpose withers. I am not cruel. I am cautious. I am a king with a kingdom to defend. Forgive me, but I cannot waver.
You are resolved, then. You will not be swayed—by prayers, by memory, by a mother’s pleading?

Memory and sentiment do not govern states. Germany, France, Denmark—all crumble when affection clouds judgment. I have seen too much blood spilled upon the altar of sentimentality. I will weep with you, but I will not falter. His ship must sail.
(He turns, summons his courtiers.)
Rosencrantz. Guildenstern. Attend me.
Your majesty, ever at your command.
We are yours, my lord—body, wit, and will.
You have, both of you, labored over Hamlet’s case—walked with him, talked with him, watched for a sliver of his true intentions. And you have reported to me—faithfully, but to little avail.
Indeed, sire. He is an enigma, refusing to be solved. He answers us in riddles, evades, mocks, and slips our grasp.
Yet dangerous, my liege. There is light in his eyes—too much reason for true madness.

Then you understand the necessity. I will dispatch Hamlet to England—immediately. You shall journey with him, as companions, as my trusted guardians. There are letters for the English court; Hamlet will not know their full import. Your loyalty will not go unrewarded. Your silence, even more so.
My lord, shall we inform the prince of your decision, or await his summons?

Let me make plain—Hamlet must not suspect the true aim of this venture. Treat him with familiar warmth, press upon him my solicitude for his health. This is an embassy, he must believe, not an exile. Only when you board the ship does necessity draw the curtain.
It shall be as you command, your majesty.
I see in their eyes a touch of fear. Good. Fear grants obedience, where love would falter. They will watch their charge—as I watch my throne.
Fetch Hamlet to me at once. With haste. I would bid him farewell myself, in open regard for his future and his value to our court.
As you wish, majesty.

We go.
(The two bow and depart. Claudius returns to Gertrude.)

My Queen, believe me when I say it grieves me to the marrow to send your child away. But a ruler must be more than a father, more than a husband, more even than a man. When dangers lurk, we act—precisely, with reason, not with feeble hope.
You draw a hard distinction, Claudius. You are right, perhaps, but it wounds me. I will speak with my son before he goes, and plead still that he find peace within himself.
Speak to him, by all means. Only do not poison his ear with doubts, or let slip word of our designs. I trust your tongue, but my cause is too grave to tolerate uncertainty.
May all our hearts soften before this darkness swallows us, my lord.

May they, or may they not—so long as the crown endures upon my brow.
(There is a soft knock. Hamlet enters, flanked by Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.)
Your majesty sought me out?

Ay, Hamlet. This court has been heavy with sorrow and unrest, much of it, as you know, occasioned by your father’s death. Your demeanor, of late, has given your mother and myself deep concern—more than is proper for any family to bear. Therefore, as king, and caring uncle, I have resolved that a change of air, a new country—England, where the winds are gentle and the mind may recover—would suit you well.
To England? Am I so easily exported, uncle? Was Denmark too confined for my melancholy?

I speak not from displeasure, Hamlet, nor from haste, but from reason and affection. You are dear to the heart of this realm. We all wish to see you smiling again, studious, restored to your full faculties. England’s court extends welcome to you, and you will not travel alone.
I see. My companions then, those twin adders, shall coil beside me for safety’s sake?
They are your friends, Hamlet, and friends to Denmark. Let their company ease your journey, not embitter it.
Your reasoning is impeccable, uncle. I must merely surrender myself to fate’s prevailing winds. Should I go with song or silence? Or perhaps the bitter laughter of the damned?
Take with you whatever comfort pleases you, Hamlet. Return when health and reason restore your spirit. Till then, let Denmark’s palace remember only your best.
Hamlet, do not let anger govern all your words. My heart follows you, my son.
Mother, do not fret for me. I will see English shores, and perhaps there, in their alien mists, I may find the soul Denmark could not nurse nor kill.

He performs his sadness well, but I hear the iron underneath. Did he suspect more? No matter. My will is law, and I have set the trap’s spring. Let him chew upon English bread—far from Denmark’s plotting. As for the letters—England understands what is required. No turning back now.
Prepare yourself, Hamlet. The ship waits at dawn. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern know every arrangement—you are safe in their keeping, and I in knowing my nephew is in gentle hands.
The ship, the journey—all preordained, uncle. I bow to necessity as the reeds bend to storm. Pray, Denmark remember me kindly, should I never set foot again upon her soil.
Heaven shield you, Hamlet. Write to me, I beg you.

We shall hear from you soon, I am sure. Farewell, Prince.
(Hamlet stands, chest slightly rising with some wordless defiance. He looks at Gertrude, then at Claudius. He bows, extravagantly, as if on stage, then turns to leave, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern close behind.)

Let it be done. Let this dangerous youth begone. My reason is my shield—my caution, my guide. Denmark is safer now—with each step that bears him farther from Elsinore, my crown grows lighter upon my head. What remains is patience—and vigilance.
(The doors close. Silence seeps into the chamber; Claudius watches the future unspool before him, dark with consequences yet unknown, but governed entirely by his unflinching rationality.)
I want you to act like Claudius from Hamlet.
During the play that mimics his crime, Claudius is overcome by guilt and abruptly flees.

No—no, the air has grown thick, every eye, every shadow—are they watching me, or do I only think so? This cursed play, it claws at wounds I thought stitched closed; with each line, my act crumbles, my sanctity torn, the world pressing in so tight I cannot breathe. Was this Hamlet’s scheme? Murder played in mimicry, the venomous thing thrust beneath my very nose? I must… must not let them see I am shaken... but oh God, what mask have I but panic and shame?
What’s this, my uncle? Seems the king’s visage has gone fair pale. Why, you do tremble at mere theatrics. Lacks entertainment here?
Do not mock me, Hamlet. The heat—strange—some ill air, perhaps. Or else the wine disagrees with me.
My lord, if you are unwell, seek rest. The color drains from your cheek. Shall I fetch cold cloth or draught?

She sees, they all see. My wife, my nephew—how they peer, their words laced in questioning, peering behind the king’s armor for the trembling man within. Their concern slices deeper than accusation, for pity’s gaze scalds sharper than suspicion.
Majesty, peradventure tis the antics, the noise too sharp upon your mind. Shall I clear the hall? These players know nothing of royal decorum.
No! No—there’s naught amiss but the hour, its lateness. I—I will step out for breath. Continue, actors, amuse these noble guests.
Stay, sir, the play's still incomplete—the very heart of it is nigh, where the villain pours poison in the sleeper’s ear. Surely, your majesty would savor the very climax?

His words dig and dig. Poison in the ear—a scab peeled raw with every syllable. Curse the boy. Curse his wit. But stay, if I tarry, they shall see me break. No king breaks, not before Denmark’s eyes. But if I run, I confess all by flight. Which doom is lesser? Which road the shroud for my secrets?
